Phagocytosis by Human Neutrophils

front.div:
SUMMARY
Innate immunity depends upon recognition of
surface features common to broad groups of
pathogens. The glucose polymer b-glucan has
been implicated in fungal immune recognition.
Fungal walls have two kinds of b-glucan:
b-1,3-glucan and b-1,6-glucan. Predominance
of b-1,3-glucan has led to the presumption that
it is the key immunological determinant for neu-
trophils. Examining various b-glucans for their
ability to stimulate human neutrophils, we find
that the minor cell wall component b-1,6-glucan
mediates neutrophil activity more efficiently
than b-1,3-glucan, as measured by engulfment,
production of reactive oxygen species, and ex-
pression of heat shock proteins. Neutrophils
rapidly ingest beads coated with b-1,6-glucan
while ignoring those coated with b-1,3-glucan.
Complement factors C3b/C3d are deposited
on b-1,6-glucan more readily than on b-1,
3-glucan. b-1,6-glucan is also important for
efficient engulfment of the human pathogen
Candida albicans. These unique stimulatory
effects offer potential for directed stimulation
of neutrophils in a therapeutic context.
